messages.content:
> I'm not sure if I could split this to one for devices and other for sessions or if I could would it be makes my total performance better.  
no that won't make it better!
logTotalCapacity is the only parameter I would care about
I think the problem here is that we don't expose the caching interface right
@Düldül Osman what browser you use and how does the time compare to compiling it in nodejs?

I'm using chrome
in nodejs
```
Compile GameToken : 3.246s
Compile offchainState : 20.862s
Compile DRM : 23.385s
```
in web workers GameToken took 30s and offchainState cannot finish compiling

here is how I create multiple instance for contracts and its offchain in worker:
https://github.com/DRM-Mina/drm-mina-web-client/blob/00754593d17976f1632feadc4c449f68c42e24dd/ui/lib/worker.ts#L69C1-L70C1
Did you find that that pattern worked in node?
yes I deployed them using same logic in nodejs
https://github.com/DRM-Mina/drm-mina-web-client/blob/4c10331425af92125fe94c47428ef34aa3cfd4da/contracts/src/scripts/buyAndRegisterDevice.ts#L40

messages.content: @Düldül Osman another parameter that you can reduce to make it less heavy is `maxActionsPerProof`. The default is 22, using something like 5 should reduce your program size a lot
So I don't thin the `Object.create` function is working as you expect.
But it's interesting that the behavior is different on node and web...

Sorry this is confusing, but I'm not aware of anyone using the offchain state API yet with multiple instances of the same contract.  It was tested only with a single instance.  Since this is an experimental API, it means we are still working on it, thanks to people like you trying it out.
I saw this but didn't change it because I didn't know exactly what it did. There was no explanation in the comments. I will try it 🤝
Yes i didn't test how it works properly, you probably right

offchain state processes pending actions in a recursive zkprogram. that parameter defines how many actions are handled in a single proof. since it's recursive, it always handles an arbitrary number of actions. but if you do less per proof then your program becomes smaller. the downside is that if you have many actions, you'll need more proofs. so, setting it to a low value optimizes for the case where there are only a few pending actions

I've observed this too, but I thought maybe it was because the instances are exactly the same except for the contract address,  maybe compile used cache and thats why second and third ones compiles very fast.
but I didn't observe 0.01ms thats too good to be working properly :D
It may be a bad metric to look at.  Maybe you still could get speed increases even with different instances working correctly.

I've added a github issue for this: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1832

@Düldül Osman feel free to add more details there!

embeds.description: Summary The way that offchain state works today is a developer will create their custom offchain state class and object in on call: const offchainState = OffchainState( { someMap: OffchainState.Map...

messages.content: with multiple instances, the offchain state class would still need to be compiled only once!
and as you've seen it just returns back to the caller if you try to compile it a second time

But how to switch between them? As I stated in here: https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1287076778644475914/1287076778644475914 
when I try to switch between offchain states it gaves me  root mismatch, maybe I used wrongly
You can't switch between them, I'm just talking hypothetically when we implement that
